qas.question: What has sociocultural anthropology been heavily influenced by?
When was there an epistemological shift away from positivist traditions in anthropology?
What questions came to occupy a central place in cultural and social anthropology?
What two fields remained largely positivist?
What have the four sub-fields of anthropology lacked over the last several decades?
what has heavily influenced structuralists and postmodern theories?
When was there a shift towards the positivist traditions?
What did archeology and biological anthropology largly shift away from?
What has been cohesive over the last several decades?

context: <b5_0>Sociocultural anthropology<b5_0/> has been heavily influenced by <a0_0>structuralist and postmodern theories<a0_0/>, as well as a shift toward the analysis of modern societies. <a1_0>During the <b6_0>1970s and 1990s<b6_0/><a1_0/>, there was an epistemological shift away from the positivist traditions that had largely informed the discipline.[page needed] During this shift, enduring questions about the <a2_0>nature and production of knowledge<a2_0/> came to occupy a central place in cultural and social anthropology. In contrast, <a3_0>archaeology and biological anthropology<a3_0/> remained largely <b7_0>positivist<b7_0/>. Due to this difference in epistemology, <b8_0>the four sub-fields of anthropology<b8_0/> have lacked <a4_0>cohesion<a4_0/> over the last several decades.
